docs.lead_paragraph: The first female overachiever of this millennium would have been Freydis, the sister of Leif Ericson. Leif was quite the millennial man himself, having stumbled on North America around the year 1000. And when the first Norse settlement there was attacked, Freydis led the defense, despite her advanced pregnancy. ''She took her breasts out and whetted the sword upon them. At that, the [enemy] became afraid and ran away,'' reported a Viking chronicler. Why, in the era of Xena and Buffy the Vampire Slayer, does this woman not have a TV series of her own? I don't know if Freydis qualifies for one of the really great women of the last thousand years -- the thing with the sword was really her best moment. The inevitable nominees from the distant past would include Queen Elizabeth I, Joan of Arc and Shikibu Murasaki, whose ''Tales of Genji'' was the first realistic novel. My own favorite is Hildegard of Bingen, a 12th-century abbess, mystic and composer who went into a trance and levitated whenever a male authority figure tried to cross her.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column recalls women's achievements over last 1,000 years in their quest to be treated equally to men; says liberation that women throughout history have fought for, or sometimes been unable to even imagine, occurred in last blink of millennium; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three weeks after press reports of Crown Princess Masako's pregnancy touched off a wave of hopeful speculation about the imperial succession, officials announced tonight that she had suffered a miscarriage. The Kyodo News Agency reported that officials said the princess had undergone surgery and was in good condition, but would remain hospitalized for an unspecified period.
docs.abstract: Japanese officials report that Crown Princess Masako has suffered a miscarriage; child could have been the first new direct heir to Japan's throne since 1965, and news of miscarriage is nearly as much of a blow to the nation's mood as to the imperial family (M)
docs.snippet: Three weeks after press reports of Crown Princess Masako's pregnancy touched off a wave of hopeful speculation about the imperial succession, officials announced tonight that she had suffered a miscarriage.    The Kyodo News Agency reported that...

docs.lead_paragraph: MIDDLE EAST IRAN: LIBERAL TELLS OF ELECTION BAN The head of the liberal Islamic opposition said all its candidates in the provinces had been barred from running in February's key parliamentary elections. ''It's the first stage in a long battle,'' Ibrahim Yazdi, secretary general of the Iran Freedom Movement, said after newspapers reported that 401 candidates of the 6,860 who applied to run had been rejected by the interior ministry. Mr. Yazdi said he had heard no word about the barring of Freedom Movement candidates in Tehran, where 30 seats are being contested. (Agence France-Presse) IRAQ: NEW FERRY LINK A second ferry line linking Iraq to other nations in the Persian Gulf has opened with the arrival of a car ferry at the Iraqi port of Um Qasr from Bahrain. Iraq, barred from international air traffic under United Nations sanctions, was permitted to open the first ferry link in the gulf last year, from Dubai. The ferries take passengers, cars and some cargo, since each passenger is allowed about 220 pounds of baggage. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: So, did it work? Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.

headline.main: Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor

docs.abstract: Last article of series, Life After Welfare, finds that Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare has left far fewer people on welfare and put more people to work, but that it has made little difference in lives of poor, socially or economically; former welfare recipients, employed in entry-level jobs, cannot afford to move from violent neighborhoods; there continue to be absent fathers, bare cupboards, epidemics of depression and temptations of drugs; street life tempts children whether parents work or not; new workers often resist workplace rules and boss's authority, prompting much job-hopping; working mothers have less time for their children; prospects of poor children may depend more profoundly on whether they have support of their fathers than whether their mothers move from subsistence welfare checks into subsistence jobs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: So, did it work?    Whatever else can be said about Wisconsin's crusade to end welfare -- whether one judges it kind or cruel, whether one thinks it left the safety net stronger or in shreds -- the effort achieved two things.

docs.lead_paragraph: GOLDENSON-Leonard H.. The Board, staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City note with profound and deep sorrow the passing of Leonard Goldenson, who helped to create both ABC and UCP. As a result of rubella during pregnancy, Leonard and Isabelle's eldest daughter, Genise, nicknamed ''Cookie'', was diagnosed with cerebral palsy. They joined other parents of children with cerebral palsy, notably Jack and Ethel Hausman and Irving Sloan, founders of UCP/NYC, to build a state-wide and national movement. Leonard recruited celebrities including Marlene Dietrich, Jinx Falkenberg, Arlene Francis, Bob Hope, Tex McCrary and Jane Pickens to support UCP and, in 1950, launched the first UCP telethon hosted by Dennis James. For nearly 50 years, both in New York City and throughout the nation, Leonard helped to make UCP the largest health organization in the U.S. He can never be replaced. We extend our condolences to Isabelle, his daughters Loreen and Maxine, and grandson Lucas. Leo Hausman, Chairman Martin C. Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Exec. Dir. Ronald J.H. Napal, Associate Executive Director, Development & Public Relations United Ceberal Palsy of NYC, Inc GOLDENSON-Leonard H. United Cerebral Palsy Associations Inc. Co-Founder and Chairman Leonard H. Goldenson died on December 27, 1999 at his home in Longboat Key, FL. He was 94 and had been ill for several years. Mr. Goldenson co-founded The United Cerebral Palsy Association in 1949. He was the first national president of UCP and served for 5 years. ''He placed UCP on the map immediately because of his television experience'', said Nina Eaton, Co-Founder of UCP. With his leadership, UCP has emerged as one of the country's largest health charities with 139 affiliates and directly serving over one million people with cerebral palsy and other disabilities. Ms. Eaton remembers working with Mr. Goldenson on the fight to advance the lives of people with disabilities and their families ''we would never have gotten where we have without him. I will miss his guidance, influence and caring spirit''. '' The entire UCP family shares the loss of Leonard Goldenson. We appreciate and remember his tremendous contributions as a charitable leader in the disability community'' said Charles H. Moses, III Esquire, President, UCPA. Nina Eaton, Co-Founder UCPA Charles H. Moses, III, Esquire President Kirsten A. Nyrop, Exec Director GOLDENSON-Leonard H. It is with deep sorrow that the Rabbis, Officers, Trustees, and members of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York record the death of our cherished Honorary Trustee, Leonard H. Goldenson. The quintessential gentleman, who possessed an outstanding intellect and generous heart, he strode as a quiet giant in the broadcast industry that so changed the nature of American and world culture during the second half of the 20th century. He was a man who achieved greatness and yet lived his life with impeccable integrity and admirable humility. He will be remembered not only for the grandeur of his achievements, but as a human being who shared his wisdom to help improve the lives of so many who were not as fortunate as he. With his beloved wife and children, we mourn his passing while giving thanks to God for the legacy he bequeaths. The memory of Leonard H. Goldenson will forever be a blessing. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary GOLDENSON-Leonard H. Faculty and staff of Harvard Medical School mourn the loss of Leonard Goldenson, a generous benefactor who had the vision to see the role of basic biomedical sciences in improving the health and well being of human kind. With is wife Isabelle, he had the foresight to invest in basic neuroscience research as a step in helping those with cerebral palsy and other neurological disorders. Our thoughts are with Isabelle and their daughters, Loreen Arbus and Maxine Goldenson. Joseph B. Martin, Dean of the Harvard Faculty of Medicine Harvard Medical School GOLDENSON-Leonard H. Leonard H. Goldenson died December 27, 1999. In addition to founding the United Cerebral Palsy Association and UCP of New York City, Mr. Goldenson was a founder of the UCP Research and Educational Foundation. His leadership of the Foundation over many years and his commitment to the people it serves will be greatly missed. Murray Goldstein, D.O., M.P.H. Director, UCP Research and Educational Foundation
